cannot agree. Since when have instructors possessed such a deathgrip over their
students? It would be just as correct to
contend that the cutting of a class symbolizes disrespectful behavior; indeed, it
would be a far more correct contention,
for last Friday the strikers evidently had
enough interest in and respect for the instructors to attend class from 10:30 to
11 a. m.
The Council's claim that the antagonism and resultant rowdyism was aroused
partly by the personnel of the strikers
may or may not have been the case.
Nevertheless, as we cannot point out
too often, this in no measure exonerates
any of those responsible for the immature display of cowardly tactics. As a
matter of fact, many did not even know
who the strike instigators were, but
were thoroughly convinced of their
boogy-man nature by older and suppos-

edly wiser heads.

Friday, April 20, 1934

Aftermath
For four long hours yesterday the
Student Council grilled all those students who were conspicuously connected
in any way with the anti-war strike held
last Friday. At midnight the Council
president and the editor of the NEWSLETTER had a personal interview, at
which time Ed Sadtler handed over the
report of the group for immediate publication and discussed at length the measures which had been enacted.
Obviously, the Council has steered a
middle course in the affair, in *that it
did not align itself definitely with one
of the two contending factions to the
total or even partial exclusion of the
other. According to the official statement as it appears on Page 1, both
parties concerned were considered guilty
in several respects, and consequently no
thorough acquittal could be tendered
either side. As far as the Council is concerned, this decision is final and the incident stands as closed.
Analyzing the report, ,step by step, we
do not approve of the Council's apparent
;censoring of the three organizations involved in the strike on the ground that
the number of their members sponsoring
the movement reached a total of less
than 50 students. We believe that the
number of the anti-war demonstrators is
irrelevant; the paramount and deciding
issue, in our eyes, is the cause for which
they were demonstrating. And we have
not changed in the least bit our opinion,
expressed in Tuesday's NEWIS-LETTER,
that that cause was, is, and forever will
be a just one and one worth striving for,
whether by one man or a million.
Our original views anent the strikers'
disrupting of the usual classroom procedure in an effort to make the Meeting more
spectacular and significant (the Council
should have used the latter adjective, too)
have also not been altered by three additional days of concentrated consideration. It was the only method, as we see
it, whereby the proper emphasis could be
placed upon the movement. After all,
asking frankly as is our wont, what loss
was suffered by the student because of
the one hour classroom interlude? And
just as frankly we answer ourselves, no
loss whatsoever. We cannot conceive of
a single course in the University which
is so much more pertinent and necessary
to the student's welfare and education,
in contrast with the question' of war,
that as a result he would consider the
sacrifice of thirty minutes an irreparable
loss. Unfortunately, we have yet to find
any study which could fill this requirement. When and'if we do, we shall
more than likely terminate this mundane
life of ours right then and there and devote the remainder of our mortal existence to the pursuit of this all-too-overpowering subject.
Then, again, we must not lose sight
of the fact that those undergraduates who
unswervingly chant "We love our
course" or who were opposed to the
meeting because of its very nature were
not compelled to attend. The former
group could have remained sequestered
with their books to their hearts' content, while the latter could have achieved
the double triumph of leaving class and
spending the following hour at leisure.
Since they were distinctly disinterested,
their presence at the meeting was certainly not prompted by any commendable
desires.
As for the "disrespectful conduct to
instructors" which this action was
deemed to have displayed, here also we

per any subsequent disturbances; no action unaccompanied by force could occomplish this end. Rather, we feel that
now that the Council has required that it
be apprised of such meetings in order that
it may aid in their proper management,
such childish issues as the personnel and
methods of procedure of the strikers will
no longer be regarded as potential arguments for would-be vandals.
We strongly advise those students who
were so severely reprimanded yesterday
to derive the moral embodied therein.
This applies especially to the freshmen,
whose all-too genuine fear could not be
masked by their affected indifference
while waiting for the Councl to pass
judgment. We urge them to recognize
at this early stage of the gafne that the
Johns Hopkins University is, in theory
at least, an institution dedicated primarily to scholarship and the search for truth
and will continue to foster and forward
such an ideal long after they have become mere names carved on classroom
table-tops. By falling into step now and
livitg this ideal, they will gain immeasurably.

Selling by telephone gets results. In many lines
of business, salesmen are finding they can cover
more customers more often—and close more sales
at lower cost—by telephone.
Bell System men have worked out a number
of plans for systematic market coverage by Long
Distance telephone. They have also devised telephone plans for more efficient handling of production, purchasing, administration, distribution,
collections.
Because Bell System service is fast, economical, adaptable to specific needs, business more and
more turns to the telephone.

Early this week the possibility
of playing the Jay-Mt. Washington contest on Friday night was
being considered in order not to

Who's Afraid Of The
Big, Bad Wolfpack

Reuben Pasarew, another one of
Hopkins' versatile athletes, was
born in Baltimore, August 12,
1914. He attended primary school
in this city and later received his
high school education at Poly Tech.
At Poly "Rube" played football,
basketball and lacrosse. In his last
year at prep school Pasarew was
captain of Poly's lacrosse team and
was chosen on the All-Maryland
scholastic team.
In the fall of 1932 "Rube" entered the Engineering School at the
Hopkins. He is specializing in the
department of Civil Engineering
and plans to make this his life work
after graduation.

Johnson Wins Handicap

The one and half mile handicap
was won by Johnson of the class
of '37. King, varsity runner, running from scratch finished in fifth
position, while Johnson was given
a lead of 200 yards.
The Jay Vee track team will
journey to Mercersburg Saturday
for a meet with the Mercersburg
Academy team. Eighteen trackmen
will make the trip.

Extra performances of "Three
Women in Love", the Hopkins
Playshop's major spring presentation, will be given next Tuesday
and Wednesday, due to the great
success it has enjoyed this week, it
has been announced by Dr. N.
Bryllion Fagin, director.
Written by Elizabeth Eager
Montefiori as an entry in the Playshop's annual competition for writers all over the country, the play is
described as a serious study of sex
and religion. It presents the dilemma of a Baptist preacher in love
with an unhappily married woman.
Since the laws of his church forbid
a minister to marry a divorced woman, he does not know what course
to follow.
The cast is made up entirely of
members of the Hopkins student
body. Tickets may be procured in
the main reading room in the library.

Finishing off a season of fifteen
contests, which included opponents
from Vermont to Florida, the Johns
Hopkins Debating Council met
Goucher College at Goucher last
Wednesday evening.
Representing the Hopkins were
Abner Willen and Walter Brecher,
debating the affirmative of the question "Resolved: That the powers of
the President of the United States
should be substantially increased as
a settled policy."
The debate was held according to
the Oregon system, by which the
first speaker gives a ten-minute constructive speech and the second
speaker cross-examines the opposing
first speaker.

in,
Si:
en

Willen Chosen President

Debating the affirmative of the
same question a few days before,
Neal Potter and Mr. Willen met the
University of Vermont, represented
by Messrs. Wilmer and Burrows,
on a trip with two others of their
debating council from Vermont to
Florida and return, meeting Hopkkins as the last of a series of fifteen on their tour.
The last meeting of the year was
held a few days ago, at which time
officers were elected for. the coming
year. Mr. Willen, veteran of three
years' work with the Council, was
selected as president of the organization to succeed Charles Squire.
Mr. Garfunkel was chosen as' business manager to take Richter Wiggall's place. Garfunkel is in his
first year at the University, and has
been a member of the freshman
team.

Friday, April 20, 1934

Aftermath
For four long hours yesterday the
Student Council grilled all those students who were conspicuously connected
in any way with the anti-war strike held
last Friday. At midnight the Council
president and the editor of the NEWSLETTER had a personal interview, at
which time Ed Sadtler handed over the
report of the group for immediate publication and discussed at length the measures which had been enacted.
Obviously, the Council has steered a
middle course in the affair, in *that it
did not align itself definitely with one
of the two contending factions to the
total or even partial exclusion of the
other. According to the official statement as it appears on Page 1, both
parties concerned were considered guilty
in several respects, and consequently no
thorough acquittal could be tendered
either side. As far as the Council is concerned, this decision is final and the incident stands as closed.
Analyzing the report, ,step by step, we
do not approve of the Council's apparent
;censoring of the three organizations involved in the strike on the ground that
the number of their members sponsoring
the movement reached a total of less
than 50 students. We believe that the
number of the anti-war demonstrators is
irrelevant; the paramount and deciding
issue, in our eyes, is the cause for which
they were demonstrating. And we have
not changed in the least bit our opinion,
expressed in Tuesday's NEWIS-LETTER,
that that cause was, is, and forever will
be a just one and one worth striving for,
whether by one man or a million.
Our original views anent the strikers'
disrupting of the usual classroom procedure in an effort to make the Meeting more
spectacular and significant (the Council
should have used the latter adjective, too)
have also not been altered by three additional days of concentrated consideration. It was the only method, as we see
it, whereby the proper emphasis could be
placed upon the movement. After all,
asking frankly as is our wont, what loss
was suffered by the student because of
the one hour classroom interlude? And
just as frankly we answer ourselves, no
loss whatsoever. We cannot conceive of
a single course in the University which
is so much more pertinent and necessary
to the student's welfare and education,
in contrast with the question' of war,
that as a result he would consider the
sacrifice of thirty minutes an irreparable
loss. Unfortunately, we have yet to find
any study which could fill this requirement. When and'if we do, we shall
more than likely terminate this mundane
life of ours right then and there and devote the remainder of our mortal existence to the pursuit of this all-too-overpowering subject.
Then, again, we must not lose sight
of the fact that those undergraduates who
unswervingly chant "We love our
course" or who were opposed to the
meeting because of its very nature were
not compelled to attend. The former
group could have remained sequestered
with their books to their hearts' content, while the latter could have achieved
the double triumph of leaving class and
spending the following hour at leisure.
Since they were distinctly disinterested,
their presence at the meeting was certainly not prompted by any commendable
desires.
As for the "disrespectful conduct to
instructors" which this action was
deemed to have displayed, here also we

per any subsequent disturbances; no action unaccompanied by force could occomplish this end. Rather, we feel that
now that the Council has required that it
be apprised of such meetings in order that
it may aid in their proper management,
such childish issues as the personnel and
methods of procedure of the strikers will
no longer be regarded as potential arguments for would-be vandals.
We strongly advise those students who
were so severely reprimanded yesterday
to derive the moral embodied therein.
This applies especially to the freshmen,
whose all-too genuine fear could not be
masked by their affected indifference
while waiting for the Councl to pass
judgment. We urge them to recognize
at this early stage of the gafne that the
Johns Hopkins University is, in theory
at least, an institution dedicated primarily to scholarship and the search for truth
and will continue to foster and forward
such an ideal long after they have become mere names carved on classroom
table-tops. By falling into step now and
livitg this ideal, they will gain immeasurably.

Selling by telephone gets results. In many lines
of business, salesmen are finding they can cover
more customers more often—and close more sales
at lower cost—by telephone.
Bell System men have worked out a number
of plans for systematic market coverage by Long
Distance telephone. They have also devised telephone plans for more efficient handling of production, purchasing, administration, distribution,
collections.
Because Bell System service is fast, economical, adaptable to specific needs, business more and
more turns to the telephone.

Early this week the possibility
of playing the Jay-Mt. Washington contest on Friday night was
being considered in order not to
conflict with the Grand National
Point-to-Point Steeplechase on
Saturday. However, the idea
was abandoned and the game

night.

Reuben Pasarew, another one of
Hopkins' versatile athletes, was
born in Baltimore, August 12,
1914. He attended primary school
in this city and later received his
high school education at Poly Tech.
At Poly "Rube" played football,
basketball and lacrosse. In his last
year at prep school Pasarew was
captain of Poly's lacrosse team and
was chosen on the All-Maryland
scholastic team.
In the fall of 1932 "Rube" entered the Engineering School at the
Hopkins. He is specializing in the
department of Civil Engineering
and plans to make this his life work
after graduation.

Johnson Wins Handicap

The one and half mile handicap
was won by Johnson of the class
of '37. King, varsity runner, running from scratch finished in fifth
position, while Johnson was given
a lead of 200 yards.
The Jay Vee track team will
journey to Mercersburg Saturday
for a meet with the Mercersburg
Academy team. Eighteen trackmen
will make the trip.

Extra performances of "Three
Women in Love", the Hopkins
Playshop's major spring presentation, will be given next Tuesday
and Wednesday, due to the great
success it has enjoyed this week, it
has been announced by Dr. N.
Bryllion Fagin, director.
Written by Elizabeth Eager
Montefiori as an entry in the Playshop's annual competition for writers all over the country, the play is
described as a serious study of sex
and religion. It presents the dilemma of a Baptist preacher in love
with an unhappily married woman.
Since the laws of his church forbid
a minister to marry a divorced woman, he does not know what course
to follow.
The cast is made up entirely of
members of the Hopkins student
body. Tickets may be procured in
the main reading room in the library.

Willen Succeeds Squire As
President; Garfunkel Is
New Business Manager

Finishing off a season of fifteen
contests, which included opponents
from Vermont to Florida, the Johns
Hopkins Debating Council met
Goucher College at Goucher last
Wednesday evening.
Representing the Hopkins were
Abner Willen and Walter Brecher,
debating the affirmative of the question "Resolved: That the powers of
the President of the United States
should be substantially increased as
a settled policy."
The debate was held according to
the Oregon system, by which the
first speaker gives a ten-minute constructive speech and the second
speaker cross-examines the opposing
first speaker.

in,

Willen Chosen President

Debating the affirmative of the
same question a few days before,
Neal Potter and Mr. Willen met the
University of Vermont, represented
by Messrs. Wilmer and Burrows,
on a trip with two others of their
debating council from Vermont to
Florida and return, meeting Hopkkins as the last of a series of fifteen on their tour.
The last meeting of the year was
held a few days ago, at which time
officers were elected for. the coming
year. Mr. Willen, veteran of three
years' work with the Council, was
selected as president of the organization to succeed Charles Squire.
Mr. Garfunkel was chosen as' business manager to take Richter Wiggall's place. Garfunkel is in his
first year at the University, and has
been a member of the freshman
team.
